Situation1: A family member has a significant event they want to share with everyone.
Expectation2: Communicate clearly and empathetically with patients and their families
Situation2: A patient has received a new diagnosis for a chronic condition and has many questions about managing it.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my granddaughter’s eyes shining as she waved a colorful drawing in front of me. “Grandpa, look! I want to show everyone at dinner tonight!” Her excitement was contagious, and I promised I’d be there, eager to see her share her moment with the family. Just as I was about to help her set the table, my phone buzzed. It was the hospital. One of my patients, Mrs. Lee, had just received a life-changing diagnosis. Her daughter was on the line, her voice trembling, asking if I could come in and explain what this meant for their family. I could hear the fear and confusion, the need for reassurance and clarity. My heart pulled in two directions—my family expecting my presence and warmth, my patient needing my guidance and compassion. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing on me, each demanding something only I could give. I stood there, torn, the sounds of my granddaughter’s laughter mixing with the distant echo of a family in distress, unsure which path to take.
